passages.text: Analyzing Argentina local markets amid high pre- electoral volatility

The upcoming elections and changes to the monetary system are driving significant volatility in domestic markets. We look at three potential types of trades to engage in the Argentinian local markets: bonds with floating rate features, RV opportunities and short- term FX carry trades. We hold 15- Dec- 26 BONTAM (last: 107.47; last FX: 1317; entry: 109.29; entry USD/ARS: 1337; FX review: 1450; includes bid/offer costs of 5 pesos for ARS and \(0.75\%\) for BONTAM; PnL: \(- 0.1\%\) ).

As the elections draw closer, markets are pricing in an increasing political risk premium. In a little over a week, EMBIG spreads have widened by \(\sim 140\mathrm{bp}\) , ARS saw a peak sell- off of \(\sim 5\%\) before recovering, and the post- elections LECAPs dated 12- Sep- 25 and 31- Oct- 25 have seen yields surge from \(49\%\) to over \(60\%\) in nominal terms before settling back to around \(50\%\) . Political factors appear to be the main drivers of such price action, namely, corruption allegations involving President Milei's inner circle, coupled with concerns about the Lower Chamber's decision on whether to overturn President Milei's vetoes on laws that would have materially increased fiscal spending. Notably, only the veto related to the disability emergency law, which has a cost of \(\sim 0.3\%\) of GDP, could be overturned if the Senate eventually decides to do so (and even then there are avenues to delay implementation; see D. Pereira), whereas the more substantial \(1.2\%\) of GDP pensions law veto was sustained, an outcome which we view positively, all things considered.

Volatility is likely to remain high ahead of the elections. Our view remains constructive, and we believe there are reasonable risk- reward trading opportunities at current levels. However, the historical significance of elections in Argentina, in a context of lower summer liquidity, is likely to keep volatility elevated in coming days. The 7 September legislative election for Buenos Aires province remains the key risk event, in our view. With \(40\%\) of the country's population voting for provincial legislators, markets will pay attention to Buenos Aires results to draw conclusions on what the 26 October national elections might bring (we note Buenos Aires has historically been a stronghold of Peronism, and there is not a 1- to- 4 relationship between the two elections).

Liquidity conditions are bound to stay tight in the near term. Since the lifting of capital controls in April, currency movements have been largely explained by liquidity conditions (Figure 1). The liquidity boost related to the LEFI removal in July was swiftly retracted, and subsequent measures by the administration have aimed to maintain tight liquidity and to therefore keep the FX stable. This has been achieved primarily by increasing reserve requirements and conducting repo operations, while also intervening in the FX derivatives market (Figure 2). Wednesday's Treasury auction achieved a \(115\%\) rollover of maturing debt, and yesterday's new regulation on banks' net position in foreign currency further supports this strategy.
See page 6 for analyst certification and important disclosures.
Figure 1: Currency movements have been largely explained by liquidity conditions since April
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P., BCRA
Figure 2: Net intervention in FX derivatives in July totaled USD 1.9bn
Source: J.P. Morgan, BCRA

1) BONTAM. These bonds pay the maximum of two legs: 1) a fixed-rate leg that capitalizes interest and works just like LECAPs or BONCAPs; and 2) a floating-rate leg that capitalizes the average monthly effective TAMAR rate during the life of the bond (see further here). As such, they offer a minimum payout based on the fixed leg but also benefit from rising yields.

Given the level of TAMAR rates since the bonds were issued, it is very likely the floating leg will determine the payment of the bonds at maturity. The TAMAR would need to average less than \(17\%\) , \(19\%\) and \(21\%\) throughout the remaining life of the March, June and December bonds, respectively, for the fixed leg to become operative (Figure 4), which seems unlikely.

Estimating the future payouts of the bonds requires modeling TAMAR paths ahead, a complex task given that both the monetary aggregates system and pre- electoral noise have added significant volatility to short- end rates. We use TAMAR expectations in the BCRA REM survey for one scenario (we note, however, since the latest one was conducted between 29 and 31 July it is likely understating current TAMAR expectations), and given the TAMAR's proximity to the policy rate in the past (Figure 3), we use real rate and inflation assumptions for four other scenarios, combining: 1) real rates based on BONCER inflation curve FRAs; 2) real rates at current levels until the elections, quickly declining to pre- elections levels afterwards and converging to \(7\%\) by the end of next year, the level deemed to be sustainable for debt by the government; 3) next 12- month inflation expectations from J.P. Morgan; and 4) next 12- month inflation expectations from BCRA REM survey. Figure 6 shows that, under our scenarios, March and December BONTAM generally screen more attractive than their closest BONCAPs, with June BONTAM having more strongly outperformed its counterpart (Figure 5).
Figure 3: High TAMAR rates have added to BONTAM's appeal
Monetary policy rate (until 10-Jul- 2025) and TAMAR deposit rate; in %
Figure 5: BONTAM have outperformed amid high rates volatility
Price ratio of BONTAM to closest LECAP/BONCAP
Figure 3: High TAMAR rates have added to BONTAM's appeal
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 4: BONTAM between are below half rent TAMAR levels

TAMAR breakevens vs. fixed leg and vs. closest LECAP/ BONCAP. Breakevens show how much the TAMAR has to average during the remaining life of the bond for it to pay the same annualized yield than the fixed leg or the LECAP/ BONCAP
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 6: March and December BONTAM have better return profiles than fixed-rate bonds
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.

2) Long LECAPs/BONCAPs and long USD/ARS via NDF. Heightened volatility, combined with a long list of government measures, has opened up room for RV trades ahead of elections. In Figure 7 we construct interpolated LECAPs and BONCAPs yields for 1m, 3m, 6m, 9m, and 12m tenors, and compare them with NDF yields. FX-hedged returns look appealing as NDF yields have lagged the move higher in domestic instruments' yields. This is a lower risk alternative ahead of elections, allowing investors to capture a spread between two similar ARS-denominated instruments without incurring FX risk. We note these are still two distinct markets, each with its own set of participants and unique liquidity conditions. As a result, spreads can develop and persist throughout the duration of the trade. The onshore nature of LECAPs and BONCAPs makes them more susceptible to changes in domestic regulation as well.
Figure 7: NDFs have generally lagged LECAPs and BONCAPs
Interpolated 1m, 3m, 6m, 9m, and 12m LECAPs/BONCAPs yields and NDF implied yields; in % (28- Aug close prices)
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.

3) Short-term carry trades. 3m NDF yields have risen by nearly 20%-pts since July-end (Figure 8), following tighter liquidity conditions locally. These yields are attractive when compared to a broad range of emerging markets and frontier high-yielding countries, both in nominal and real terms (Figure 10and Figure 11). Additionally, the top FX band, currently 11% above the USD/ARS level and growing at a 1% monthly rate (Figure 9), offers some protection against FX depreciation in the near term.
Figure 8: NDF implied yields are above 50% for 1m and 3m
Figure 9: The top band is 11% above current FX levels
Source: J.P. Morgan, Bloomberg Finance L.P.
Figure 10: Argentina's nominal carry is appealing among other high-yielders in EM and frontier marketsImplied 3m NDF yield; %
Source: J.P.Morgan, Bloomberg Finance, L.P.
Figure 11: In real terms, the carry differential is also quite pronounced
Source: J.P.Morgan, Bloomberg Finance, L.P.

Ratings System: J.P. Morgan uses the following issuer portfolio weightings for Emerging Markets Sovereign Research: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns); Marketweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark credit returns). NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this security because of either legal, regulatory or policy reasons or because of lack of a sufficient fundamental basis. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. Recommendations will be at the issuer level, and an issuer recommendation applies to all of the index- eligible bonds at the same level for the issuer. When we change the issuer- level rating, we are changing the rating for all of the issues covered, unless otherwise specified. Ratings for quasi- sovereign issuers in the EMBIG may differ from the ratings provided in EM corporate coverage.

Valuation & Methodology: For J.P. Morgan's Emerging Markets Sovereign Research, we assign a rating to each sovereign issuer (Overweight, Marketweight or Underweight) based on our view of whether the combination of the issuer's fundamentals, market technicals, and the relative value of its securities will cause it to outperform, perform in line with, or underperform the credit returns of the EMBIG index over the next three months. Our view of an issuer's fundamentals includes our opinion of whether the issuer is becoming more or less able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable, as well as whether its willingness to service debt obligations is increasing or decreasing.
